job_title: Business Development Manager in London, England

review_title: Great team and family friendly working policies
job_title: Global Leadership Manager in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros:
Since being with VSO I have met and worked with amazing people both in the UK and Internationally. I have found colleagues to be welcoming, friendly and supportive. In the UK we have regular meet ups and social activities like playing sport, walks, lunches and after work drinks.

The flexible working policies have been really helpful in supporting me to manage caring responsibilities and family emergencies.

As for career progression, I have been fortunate to have had 2 promotions over the last 7 years. This has kept me engaged, progressing and learning.
cons:
There are limited external formal training and qualifications offered and paid for, however staff do have access to an internal online training platform. 

It feels like change is not communicated very well (i.e. during the pandemic), however there are regular monthly calls with leadership where staff can get information and ask questions that I have found somewhat useful.

review_title: Great place to work with great cause
job_title: Data Analyst in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Great people and great cause
cons: Job security is always the worry in the non-profit sector

review_title: Wonderful Colleagues at an organisation trying to respond in a challenging sector
pros: Great, dedicated colleagues based across the world bringing different opinions, viewpoints and contexts to collaboration. I've been able to progress internally a number of times and had opportunities to work in different areas. Flexible working is possible and I've been able to maintain a good work-life balance.
cons: As is the case across the development/aid sector, VSO is trying to respond to changing funding situations and development trends. This means that the organisation has, and continues to, go through periods of change and reorganisation which can be challenging at times to navigate. This is not unique to VSO and my experience on the whole has been that decisions have been made that benefit the organisation with a focus on outcome for primary actors which is where the focus should be!

pros: fully remote once covid started and looking to make this a permanent feature. flat management structure so you are heard.
cons: can be reactionary regarding organisational changes. not very flexible on issues such as pay

pros: Empowerment innovative fair nice place to work
cons: Over complicated process challenges with accoutability

pros: supportive organisation and great colleagues to work with. Lots of development opportunities
cons: Funding can affect instability of employment

pros: Flexible work hours and working from home

review_title: A nice place to work but no progression
job_title: Resourcing Advisor in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros:
Working from home encouraged
Flexible working
Nice office
Open planned office
Hot desking
cons:
Office hard to get to - very bad train links

Bulling across the UK office especially in the resourcing team. Higher management are aware but ignore it if it is their friends doing the bullying. The ceo and HR were even aware of three cases of bullying and nothing was done about it. The bully even got promoted to manage a larger team, which resulted in most of them leaving because of the bullying continuing. 

No progression
Low pay for london
Management  do not care about staff only help their close friends
Ceo is rarely in the office or speaks to employees 
Every year there is a restructure
Low staff morale from money being wasted on higher management traveling but junior staff members do not even get pay rises in line with the london market

Salary review done but not comparing london based companies

No job secruity as always making cuts

No benefits for working there for a long period of time 

IT equipment very old and usually broken

Lots of people with manager in their job title but do not actually manage anyone and are paid at a managers wage. But the junior staff are over worked and under paid.

Toxic environment in the resourcing team caused by higher management and managers. If an exit survey was done on this team the ceo would be shocked how toxic it is.

pros: VSO is an integral organisation with great staff, a clean and presentable environment and a clear vision. Highly recommend.
cons: Some roles can be unstable due to government funding.

job_title: Logistics Coordinator in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Lovely people and very interesting work
cons: None really - great company and people

pros: Kind team members, support with training opportunities
cons: Lack of transparency and a lot of restructuring

job_title: Resourcing Advisor in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Flexible working, good holidays, good work-life balance, strong vision and mission
cons: Low pay, lack of progression, lack of diversity (at CMU UK level), blame from senior management, very cliquey (CMU)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros:
The strategy is clearer, communicated broadly and discussed with employees. It makes it easier to know where we're going and which initiative to prioritise.
Management is very approachable (in particular our CEO) and willing to be challenged.
Accountability and decision-making is distributed at all levels of the organisation allowing us to be more reactive and innovative.
The work environment and atmosphere is very stimulating and there are many very talented and motivated people at VSO which gives me daily opportunities to learn and get involved in new projects or just interesting conversations over lunch.
Technology enables us to share a lot of information and to work together even when we are based in very remote locations. I personally have daily contacts with Kenya, Thailand and South Africa, and weekly catch ups with teammates in Bangladesh, Tanzania and many other countries.
cons: The UK office is a bit far from London and travel is time-consuming (working from home helps a lot).

job_title: Acting Head of Programs in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Very good at supporting new initiatives and capacitating staff to deliver quality outputs. Innovative ,model of placing volunteers in organizations to strengthen organizational capacity.
cons: Week funding abilities, too much dependence on Core funding, with limited diversified funding options.  Too much powers entrusted in the hand of  HQ manages who understand very little about fiend realities and contextual decisions. Most HQ decisions are based on limited feedback which most often is not verified

job_title: Fundraising Coordinator in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Lots of flexibilty in roles and opportunity to input your own ideas and manage projects even at a junior level. The team are encouraging of dispersed leadership and not very hierarchical. Lots of change. Lots of annual leave.
cons: High staff turnover can be demotivating, lots of restructures and what feels like a lack of understanding from management of how big picture changes affect day-to-day work; lots of pressure put on junior roles to accommodate and take on responsibility. Lack of internal coordination across organisation, as a fundraiser you feel very distant from the work and it is difficult to find information.

review_title: Overall not a great place to work
pros:
Flexible working is very good, although this is largely down to the fact the office is so difficult to get to. It also depends on your team as some have more flexible working than others.
Flat management structure means you can be creative in how you work and achieve your objectives.
cons: No career progression opportunities. The Global Strategy is very top line and as a result no one is very clear on what they need to do to deliver it. Not enough investment in country office staff, particularly those who are at the coal face and work really hard.

pros: Focus on core development outcomes. Leader for volunteering for development. Flexible working
cons: Some teams have a hierarchical  view and consider their work superior to others, rather than working effectively with other teams to achieve the most effective and positive outcome. There is a negative view internally about the value of youth for development, however, this is VSO's largest contract. The organisation therefore needs to be less rigid and more agile to move with current trends and achievements.

review_title: Rewarding in many ways but overall lack of identity an issue.
pros: The people are passionate, mostly hardworking and share common values. Programme work is effective and makes a real difference in most cases.
cons: Poor investment and over reliance of institutional funding has harmed VSO over the years. Lack of income diversity shapes the organisation rather than the management.

review_title: Don't work here if you are a fundraiser
pros:
- There are some nice  and willing people.
- Flexible working hour
- Salary is relatively good
cons:
- Programme teams have louder voice than fundraising. Senior management don't care about public fundraising at all. If you are a fundraising professional, don't work here!
- No one dares to make any decision whatsoever if it is something new. Even the smallest thing will end up in long email chain with all sorts of people cc.ed in without any decision.
- The moral in the Kingston office has been really low for a long time and the senior management not only ignore it but also try to sweep it under the rug.
- Spent ungodly amount of money on external agencies to do everything instead of spending money to train the staff. The staff becomes a messenger passing along the email and that's all.
- Looks at only quick wins without thinking long term.
- A lot of lazy staff can get away with doing almost nothing at VSO. Some people abuse the flexible working  and are either constantly nowhere to be found during their "work from home" day or "work from home" more than 3 days a week. This really make those who need things from them and have decent work ethic feel extremely frustrated. 
- Top management fails to find suitable candidate for a lot of mid-senior management roles. They have no idea what kind of person they need and they never ask the staff about anything. Basically the team is running without a long term leaderships.
- After the big restructures around two years ago, a lot of things they did at that time are or about to be undone. Some people were 'bullied' out (e.g. got placed in a new position that didn't fit their skillets) then, and a lot of new people came after the restructure are gone again already.
- A lot of incapable people can get away with working at this organisation for years and years. Good people never stay long here.

pros: Working with lots of inspirational and likeminded people who are passionate about doing good. A generally fun and casual working environment.
cons: Although an international organisation, limited opportunities to travel and visit programmes. Higher up within the organisation it all got a bit cliquey and certain people were favoured more for the exciting opportunities. Little career progression and limited professional development.

review_title: Collaboration to deliver is what it's all about
pros: Collaborative, truly-global, flexible ways of working, focused on the mission, innovative in their approaches
cons: If you're working in the UK, it sometimes feels a long way from the front-line of our work.

pros: A strong atmosphere of collaboration and engagement.  Great opportunity to work with global colleagues
cons: No real downsides, just lots to do.!
